verses.text: Now the queen of Sheba heard about Solomon’s fame concerning the name of the Lord, and she came to test him with hard questions.
verses.comment: Preserved the sense of 'testing with hard questions' rather than 'riddles' for clarity.

verses.text: She arrived in Jerusalem with a very great caravan—with camels carrying spices, a lot of gold, and precious stones. She came to Solomon and spoke with him about all that was on her mind.
verses.comment: ‘Caravan’ used for readability; 'all that was on her mind' for accuracy.

verses.text: Solomon answered all her questions; nothing was too difficult for the king to explain to her.
verses.comment: ‘Too difficult’ matches the Hebrew phrase for 'hidden.'

verses.text: When the queen of Sheba saw all Solomon’s wisdom, the palace he had built,
the food on his table, the seating of his officials, the service of his attendants and their clothing, his cupbearers, and the burnt offerings he made at the temple of the Lord, she was overwhelmed.
verses.comment: ‘Overwhelmed’ used as a modern rendering of ‘no more spirit in her’.

verses.text: She said to the king, “The report I heard in my own country about your achievements and your wisdom was true.
But I did not believe the reports until I came myself and saw with my own eyes. Indeed, not even half was told to me; your wisdom and prosperity surpass the stories I heard.
How happy your men must be! How happy your servants who continually stand before you and hear your wisdom!
verses.comment: ‘Happy’ for ‘blessed’ reflects the modern idiom with same original meaning.

verses.text: Blessed be the Lord your God, who has delighted in you and set you on the throne of Israel. Because of his love for Israel, he has made you king to carry out justice and righteousness.

Then she gave the king one hundred and twenty talents of gold, a very great quantity of spices, and precious stones. Never again did such an abundance of spices come as what the queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.
verses.comment: ‘Never again did such an abundance...’ is a smoothing but accurate.

verses.text: The fleet of Hiram, which brought gold from Ophir, also brought large amounts of almug wood and precious stones from Ophir.

From the almug wood the king made supports for the temple of the Lord and for the royal palace, as well as lyres and harps for the musicians. Such almug wood has not been seen or brought here again to this day.
verses.comment: ‘Supports’ for ‘pillars’ for contemporary readability; preserves meaning.

verses.text: King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba whatever she desired, whatever she asked for, besides what he had given her out of his royal bounty. Then she returned to her own country, she and her servants.
The weight of gold that came to Solomon each year was six hundred and sixty-six talents of gold,
not counting what came from merchants and traders and from all the Arabian kings and the governors of the land.
King Solomon made two hundred large shields of hammered gold; six hundred shekels of gold went into each shield.
He made three hundred small shields of hammered gold; three minas of gold went into each shield. The king put them in the House of the Forest of Lebanon.
verses.comment: ‘Small shields’ for ‘bucklers’; ‘House of the Forest of Lebanon’ preserved as is.

verses.text: The king also made a great throne of ivory and overlaid it with pure gold.
The throne had six steps, and its back had a rounded top. There were armrests on either side of the seat, and two lions stood beside the armrests.
verses.comment: ‘Rounded top’ for precise translation of ‘the top of the throne was round at the back.’

verses.text: Twelve lions stood there, one on each end of the six steps. Nothing like it had ever been made for any other kingdom.
All King Solomon’s drinking vessels were gold, and all the vessels of the House of the Forest of Lebanon were pure gold. None were of silver; silver was not considered valuable in Solomon’s days.
For the king’s fleet sailed to Tarshish with Hiram’s sailors; once every three years it returned, bringing gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks.
So King Solomon surpassed all the kings of the earth in wealth and wisdom.
The whole world sought the audience of Solomon to hear the wisdom God had put in his heart.
Year after year, everyone who came brought gifts—articles of silver and gold, garments, weapons, spices, horses, and mules.
Solomon accumulated chariots and horsemen; he had fourteen hundred chariots and twelve thousand horsemen, and he stationed them in the chariot cities and with the king at Jerusalem.
The king made silver as common in Jerusalem as stones, and cedars as plentiful as sycamore trees in the lowlands.
Solomon’s horses were imported from Egypt and from Kue; the king’s traders purchased them from Kue for a price.
verses.comment: ‘Kue’ for precise geographical rendering; some translations say ‘Keveh’ or ‘Cilicia.’

verses.text: A chariot imported from Egypt cost six hundred shekels of silver, and a horse cost one hundred and fifty. They also exported them to all the kings of the Hittites and the kings of Aram.
verses.comment: ‘Exported’ clarifies for modern readers; otherwise direct.
